*G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2*.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to *G.L. c. 223, § 2* because the tortious conduct occurred within this judicial district at 45 Market Street, Lowell, Massachusetts.

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 362 Mass. 165, 167 (1972)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant, through its employees, agents, and managers, owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in the maintenance, stacking, and display of merchandise to prevent foreseeable harm to customers lawfully on the premises.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case concerns insurance coverage, ownership of an aircraft, and the insured’s fraud and non-cooperation with the insurer. It does not involve premises liability, the duty of a business to customers, or the maintenance/stacking/display of merchandise. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant owes a duty of reasonable care in the maintenance and display of merchandise to protect customers from foreseeable harm.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: "According to the terms of the policy, the named insured, George H. Perry d/b/a Narragansett Airways, ‘is the sole owner of the aircraft . . . and loss, if any, . . . shall be payable ... to the named Insured and: Fall River National Bank.’ However, the judge was warranted in finding that prior to the time of the accident Perry had transferred ownership of the aircraft to Joyce Gilbert... On these facts alone, the plaintiff was relieved of any obligation to appear and defend Perry."

*G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 231, § 85*, every person or entity conducting activities in the Commonwealth owes a duty to act with reasonable care under the circumstances.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, a business invitee lawfully on the premises, a duty to maintain the store in a reasonably safe condition and to protect him from foreseeable injury.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring opinion discussing the classification of entrants (trespasser/licensee/invitee) and criticizing reliance on such labels. It does not state or apply a specific rule about a business invitee or a duty to maintain a store in reasonably safe condition. While the broader Mounsey decision deals with occupier liability, this particular cited page and passage do not clearly support the specific proposition claimed.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, a business invitee lawfully on the premises, a duty to maintain the store in a reasonably safe condition and to protect him from foreseeable injury.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses and applies the modern Massachusetts premises-liability rule that a property owner owes lawful visitors (including invitees such as customers) a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and protect them from foreseeable harm. The court expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and holds that snow-and-ice hazards are subject to the same duty of reasonable care owed to all lawful visitors, including business invitees like the plaintiff shopper at Target.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Coughlin v. T.M. Holmes & Co.*, 310 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s concussion, shoulder strain, and related damages.
*Coughlin v. T.M. Holmes & Co.*, 310 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion does not decide or discuss whether the defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s physical injuries. Instead, it addresses a procedural issue: whether a prior judgment of nonsuit should be vacated due to the plaintiff’s abnormal mental condition and whether he had a potentially meritorious cause of action. The court merely finds there was enough evidence of a possibly meritorious claim to justify vacating the judgment, not that negligence proximately caused specific injuries such as concussion or shoulder strain.
*Coughlin v. T.M. Holmes & Co.*, 310 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “There was sufficient evidence to satisfy the requirement that the petitioner must have a meritorious cause of action worthy of a trial in court. Russell v. Foley, 278 Mass. 145, 148. There was evidence that the petitioner when struck was walking across a forty-foot street and that, although he was half way across, the respondent did not see him until he was a foot or two from the respondent’s right front mudguard.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s concussion, shoulder strain, and related damages.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Jupin v. Kask concerns duty and, more broadly, the elements of negligence, but the court expressly states that questions of causation and the extent of damages are for the jury, not decided in this opinion. The case does not hold that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of any particular injuries; it only reverses summary judgment on duty so that a jury may determine breach, causation, and damages. Thus it does not support a proposition that defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of plaintiff’s concussion, shoulder strain, and related damages.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable result of Defendant’s failure to secure heavy boxes appropriately.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition that the injuries were a foreseeable result of the defendant’s failure to secure heavy boxes. Thus, the case (at least as reflected in this excerpt) rejects, rather than supports, the asserted foreseeability proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: Plaintiff did not contribute negligently to his injuries and acted with reasonable care at all times.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: The opinion in Ulwick v. DeChristopher concerns whether a social host owed a duty to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest; it does not analyze or decide whether the plaintiff (a police officer on a motorcycle) was free from contributory or comparative negligence. The court’s reasoning and holding focus exclusively on the host’s duty and control over alcohol, not on the plaintiff’s own conduct or standard of care. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition that the plaintiff acted with reasonable care and did not contribute negligently to his injuries.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff claims that these circumstances impose a common law duty in negligence on the defendant for the protection of travelers on the highways. The question whether the defendant owed a duty to travelers who might be injured by the negligent driving of an intoxicated guest who had been at the defendant's party presents 'a question of law....'"

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions, Plaintiff suffered physical pain, emotional distress, lost wages, medical expenses, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The proposition is a standard causation-and-damages allegation in a negligence claim (physical pain, emotional distress, lost wages, medical expenses, loss of enjoyment of life). Payton does not set out or endorse that damages formulation; instead it addresses whether Massachusetts recognizes a cause of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm and describes required elements for such a claim. The opinion is about the availability and limits of emotional-distress recovery, not about the general range of compensable negligence damages listed in the proposition.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case." 386 Mass. at 557.

*Aleksov v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 4.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions, Plaintiff suffered physical pain, emotional distress, lost wages, medical expenses, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Aleksov v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal appeal in a first-degree murder case dealing with evidentiary rulings, jury instructions, and § 33E review. It does not address civil negligence, causation standards, or categories of compensable damages such as pain and suffering, emotional distress, lost wages, medical expenses, or loss of enjoyment of life. Therefore, it provides no authority for the pleaded tort damages proposition and appears to be an inapposite citation.

*G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B*.proposition: Plaintiff seeks fair compensation for all lawful damages pursuant to *G.L. c. 231, § 6B* (interest on damages in tort actions).

*G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 13*.proposition: C. Costs of this action pursuant to *Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d)* and *G.L. c. 261, § 13*;
